title: 105_hr2461
content: The "First Flight Commemorative Coin Act of 1997" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The coin specifications are outlined in section 2. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $10 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The coins minted under this Act will have a diameter of 1.205 inches and be minted to the specifications for half dollar coins. They shall be legal tender. The Secretary will obtain gold and silver for minting coins under this Act from various sources, including silver stockpiles established under other laws. The design of the coins will adhere to specifications for half dollar coins. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall commemorate the first flight of Orville and Wilbur Wright in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina in 1903. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2003", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the First Flight Foundation and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of the coins minted under this Act commemorates the first flight of Orville and Wilbur Wright in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina in 1903, with inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act from August 1, 2003, to July 31, 2004, with a possible 5-year extension for coins with sufficient public demand. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges will apply to all sales. The Secretary will sell coins at prices ranging from $1 to $35 per coin, with marketing expenses covered to promote the coins minted under the Act. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be paid to the First Flight Foundation for maintaining the Wright Brothers Monument and National Memorial Park in North Carolina. The Comptroller General can audit the Foundation's expenditures. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary will ensure that minting coins will not cost the government. SEC. 10. WAIVER OF COIN PROGRAM RESTRICTIONS. Coins minted under this Act are exempt from certain restrictions, with surcharge proceeds going towards National Park projects.
